title.narrative: B4D Pacto Motor Ungdomar och sysselsättning

description.narrative:
Stiftelsen Fundación Neme har ansökt till Sveriges Ambassad i Bogotá om finansiering på 4,8 miljoner SEK till projektet Pacto Motor i Colombia under perioden 2014-2016.
Insatsen syftar till att skala upp en nyetablerad teknisk yrkesutbildning inom transport- och fordonsindustrin som genomförs vid Centro Juan Bosco Obrero i Bogotá, Ciudad Don Bosco i Medellín och Centro Don Bosco i Cali. Institutionerna tillhör Salesian Missions, världens största leverantör av teknisk yrkesutbildning. Utbildningsprogrammet riktar sig till marginaliserade ungdomar i åldern 17-29 år som lidit offer för den interna väpnade konflikten eller som befinner sig i en situation där de riskerar att rekryteras till illegala väpnade grupper.
Insatsen utgör en offentlig-privat aktörssamverkan där privata och offentliga aktörer gemensamt driver och finansierar insatsen. Av den totala budgeten på 17,0 MSEK står det svenska bidraget för 28,2 %, vilket går till finansiering av teknisk yrkesutbildning för 380 ungdomar, samt utvecklande av ett system för uppföljning och utvärdering. Privata företag, främst General Motors och Chaneme Group, bidrar med 42,2 % av den totala budgeten. Borgmästarämbetet i Bogotá samt Myndigheten för socialt välstånd finansierar resterande 29,6 % av budgeten.

The foundation Fundación Neme has applied to the Embassy of Sweden in Bogotá for funding of the Project Pacto Motor in Colombia during the period 2014-2016.
The development intervention aims to scale up a newly established technical vocational training programme within the transport and automotive industries, implemented by Centro Juan Bosco Obrero in Bogotá, Ciudad Don Bosco in Medellín and Centro Don Bosco in Cali. The institutions all belong to Salesian Missions, the world's largest provider of vocational training programmes. The target group for the development intervention is marginalized youth aged 17-29 years, victims of the internal armed conflict or that faces the risk of being recruited to illegal armed groups.
The development intervention composes a public-private partnership where private companies in conjunction with public entities implement and finance the intervention. The intervention’s total budget amounts to SEK 17 million. The Swedish contribution covers 28.2 % of the total budget, and is designated to 380 quotas of the vocational training as well as the development of a monitoring and evaluation system. Private companies, first and foremost General Motors and Chaneme Group, contribute with 42.2 % of the total budget. The Mayor's Office of Bogotá and the national Department for Social Prosperity finance the remaining 29.6% of the budget.

To improve employability conditions of youths that are victims of the internal armed conflict in Colombia, or encountered in a state of vulnerability or poverty, in marginalized urban areas of Bogotá, Medellín and Cali.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

description.narrative: Ruta Motor through different partners has provided vocation training in 6 different programs to 890 vulnerable young (34% women) in the three selected cities (Bogota, Medellin and Cali). With a desertion rate of 44%, by the end of the project, 332 youth have formal employment and 63 have decided to continue higher education. Between October and December 2017 an external evaluation was held including interviews to 52 young participants and representatives from all the relevant institutions such as SENA, ICBJ, Companies. The external evaluation has shown positive impact in the young participants, the Neme Foundation has exceeded the set goals and therefore the first phase has been evaluated as effective, relevant, with sustainable results. Some conclusions are that the program has been relevant and has adapted to each local context. The program has been effective as the main goals have been achieved with high participation of stakeholders. The program has also been efficient with the use of financial resources and time articulation with stakeholders. The program has also shown important impact in participants and companies. It showed that 94% of 103 participating companies were satisfied with young abilities and had evaluated 4 or 5 over 5 the level of satisfaction. In addition, 81% of young participants felt that they are more empowered and better recognized in their neighborhood. Their self-esteem has increased and they have developed a new project of life with open opportunities they did not have before the program. 24% of young participants have increased the familiar relationships. The soft and hard skills acquired are sustainable over time.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
